text:
TAMAQUA

Tamaqua police Incidents reported

Tamaqua police reported the following:

\-- Steven P. Campbell, 50, Tamaqua, was walking through a parking lot at 120
Pine St. on May 21 around 11 a.m. when police stopped to talk to him, finding
he had packets of suspected marijuana on him. He faces possession of a
controlled substance and possession of drug parpahernalia.

\-- Uzair Jasim W. Williams, 21, Barnesville, faces unsworn falsification,
false identification to law enforcement and driving with a suspended license
after police stopped his vehicle at Pine and Biddle streets on May 22 at 11:50
p.m. and he provided a false name. As it turned out, he was wanted for failure
to appear.

HAZLETON

Investigation of attempted bicycle theft underway

Hazleton police is investigating an attempted theft of bicycles.

It happened in the 400 block of West Oak Street on May 31, just before 11 a.m.
During the theft a blue Schwinn Ranger mountain bike was left in the area and
was taken to the police station for the owner to claim.

CONYNGHAM

Man accused of pointing gun at neighbor

A Conyngham man faces charges after his neighbor said he pointed a gun at his
head.

William A. Swire, 40, faces misdemeanors for simple assault and terroristic
threats and a summary count of disorderly conduct.

He was released on $1,000 unsecured bail on May 27 by Magisterial District
Judge Michael Dotzel, Wilkes-Barre.

Arrest papers state police were called to 27 Sachse Ave. on May 26 for a
neighbor dispute, finding Swire leaving the area with a long gun when they
arrived.

The neighbor told police Swire came to his home, accused him of stealing his
lawn trimmer and pointed a rifle at his head, threatening to shoot him if it
wasn't returned, court papers state. The neighbor's wife and children
witnessed the incident, police wrote.

RUSH TWP.

Woman faces theft charges

Rush Twp. police charged a woman after being called to a theft at a Hometown
store.

Maryann E. Hudachek, 42, West Hazleton, faces retail theft and receiving
stolen property after the May 12 incident at Walmart in Hometown.

She was released on $15,000 unsecured bail set by Magisterial District Judge
David Rossi.

Arrest papers state Hudachek was spotted running out of the store and getting
into an Audi after loss prevention workers saw a woman putting clothing items
totaling $42.25 into a bag.

title: Police For June 5

TAMAQUA

Tamaqua police Incidents reported

Tamaqua police reported the following:

-- Steven P. Campbell, 50, Tamaqua, was walking through a parking lot at 120 Pine St. on May 21 around 11 a.m. when police stopped to talk to him, finding he had packets of suspected marijuana on him. He faces possession of a controlled substance and possession of drug parpahernalia.

-- Uzair Jasim W. Williams, 21, Barnesville, faces unsworn falsification, false identification to law enforcement and driving with a suspended license after police stopped his vehicle at Pine and Biddle streets on May 22 at 11:50 p.m. and he provided a false name. As it turned out, he was wanted for failure to appear.

It happened in the 400 block of West Oak Street on May 31, just before 11 a.m. During the theft a blue Schwinn Ranger mountain bike was left in the area and was taken to the police station for the owner to claim.

A Conyngham man faces charges after his neighbor said he pointed a gun at his head.

William A. Swire, 40, faces misdemeanors for simple assault and terroristic threats and a summary count of disorderly conduct.

He was released on $1,000 unsecured bail on May 27 by Magisterial District Judge Michael Dotzel, Wilkes-Barre.

Arrest papers state police were called to 27 Sachse Ave. on May 26 for a neighbor dispute, finding Swire leaving the area with a long gun when they arrived.

The neighbor told police Swire came to his home, accused him of stealing his lawn trimmer and pointed a rifle at his head, threatening to shoot him if it wasn’t returned, court papers state. The neighbor’s wife and children witnessed the incident, police wrote.

Maryann E. Hudachek, 42, West Hazleton, faces retail theft and receiving stolen property after the May 12 incident at Walmart in Hometown.

She was released on $15,000 unsecured bail set by Magisterial District Judge David Rossi.
